III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications.
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation A staff member at the facility has been taking payouts to cover up
sexual abuse occurring at the facility.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone by the MDHHS
Worker on March 11, 2025. Complainant said he was aware of
Clinical Supervisor receiving extra money from the facility about
two to three years ago. Complainant reported he recently heard in
the news there was allegations of cover-up of sexual abuse
occurring at the facility and assumed that the money Clinical
Supervisor had received was from assisting in this cover-up.
Chief Operating Officer was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on March 13, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker. Chief Operating Officer said the facility has provided
bonuses depending on the year-end budget. Chief Operating
Officer said facility wide bonuses would have been given in
December for all employees. Chief Operating Officer said the
facility does not give out individual employee bonuses so Clinical
Supervisor would never have been given a bonus that other
employee’s did not receive. Chief Operating Officer said the
facility had provided special bonuses for the direct care shift
workers for COVID, snow days, and currently offer a shift premium
for third shift employees however stated this would not include
Clinical Supervisor as she is salaried. Chief Operating Officer
denied having any knowledge of Clinical Supervisor getting any
“payoff” for covering anything up at the facility. Chief Operating
Officer denied having any knowledge of a sexual abuse cover up
occurring with Clinical Supervisor or any other staff at the facility.
Clinical Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on March 13, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Clinical Supervisor said she has worked for the Whaley Children’s
Center on and off since the fall of 2017. Clinical Supervisor said
she started as a direct care worker then left and obtained her
bachelor’s degree and returned as a case manager in 2018.
Clinical Supervisor said she left again in 2020 to finish her
master’s degree and returned in March 2021 as a therapist and
was most recently promoted to Clinical Supervisor in August of
2024. Clinical Supervisor said while she was a therapist she
worked with the youth in all three Whaley programs. Clinical
Supervisor said she has been given pay increases due to position
changes, and in the fall of 2022 was going to take a position for a
different organization and was offered a pay increase to stay at
Whaley Children’s Center. Clinical Supervisor said she can only
remember one or two times that she received a small bonus in her
paycheck, denying it occurs regularly. Clinical Supervisor denied
2

ever taking money or any gifts to cover up sexual abuse at the
facility. Clinical Supervisor said if she was made aware of any
sexual abuse it would be called into child protective services for
investigation, and she would notify her supervisor about the
allegations.
Chief Program Officer was interviewed via telephone on
March 18, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Chief
Program Officer said she has supervised Clinical Supervisor for
the last several years in her current role and as a therapist. Chief
Program Officer said she has not had any concerns or issues with
Clinical Supervisor throughout the entire time she has supervised
her. Chief Program Officer said she is not part of the decision for
employee bonuses. Chief Program Officer said she is not aware of
Clinical Supervisor receiving any money or gifts for covering up
sexual abuse. Chief Program Officer said she has no knowledge
of Clinical Supervisor not reporting sexual abuse or covering up
any sexual abuse. Chief Program Officer said all employees are
expected to report sexual abuse allegations to child protective
services and she has no reason to believe Clinical Supervisor has
not followed that policy.
Documents Reviewed:
• Clinical Supervisor’s personnel file was reviewed:
o There was no disciplinary record.
o Background checks were most recently completed
on October 28, 2024, with no criminal charges or
central registry confirmations.
o Annual evaluations were completed and did not
have any concerns noted.
o Bonus record was reviewed and she, along with all
employees, were given bonuses on December 23,
2021, and November 30, 2022.
o Compensation Detail Record for 3/24/2017-
3/14/2025 was reviewed. All payments to Clinical
Supervisor were reviewed. Payments aligned with
paychecks and the two bonuses noted above.
o Pay Rate History was reviewed showing Clinical
Supervisor’s pay history based on the several job
roles changes and two bonuses noted above.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there is no evidence that
Clinical Supervisor was given payment or gift to cover up sexual
abuse occurring at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
